posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
We're thinking about redesigning our practice bot's elevator this summer to use continuous rigging instead of cascade. While primarily this is for practice, we're also evaluating whether a continuous elevator could be simpler or more efficient, particularly with more than 2 stages.

We've never constructed a continuous elevator before, so seeking advice is crucial. Looking at similar discussions, can anyone share their experiences or tips?

Our team prioritizes reliability and learned from last year's issues with stripped elevator belts. Teams using HTD Belt Rigging faced challenges, with many teams using a spool made from 1 to 2-inch OD tubing (as demonstrated by team 111). Questions remain: how many wraps are optimal, how to manage movement left and right, and whether eliminating the fixed anchor could help reduce spool size while maintaining tension consistency.

Alternative methods involve looping the rope between two counter-rotating spools, as shown by @clydefrog88 and @Programming4907. However, concerns about the system's effectiveness persist.

Maintaining rope tension is another consideration. We're unsure if a ratcheting drum anchor alone suffices or if additional tension springs are necessary.

Lastly, we seek advice on building and operating continuous elevators, focusing on reliability, ease of construction, and potential pitfalls.

link_counts.title: 34' x 18mm Wide Kevlar Backed Timing Belt (HTD 5mm) â€“ WestCoast Products

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: Another option which might package better is to loop the rope back and forth between two counter-rotating spools. Our pulleys weren't counter-rotating, and we didn't like how the rope rubs on itself. Instead, we used circular grooves in each pulley and offset the top and bottom spools by half a groove. This ensures the rope moves over by one full groove from top to bottom and back again, keeping the spool-off points consistent. Ideally, the connection point on the elevator should align with these spool-off points for optimal performance.

Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year. For teams that used HTD Belt rigging this year - what worked and what didnâ€™t? We used cascade also but with belts and custom machined UHMW pulleys for moving the cascade stage â€“ it held up really well. We used this belt specifically: Gates LL5MR09 Belt. If we had chosen to rig it continuous-style, I didnâ€™t see anything this year that would give me pause using the same parts in that sort of configuration. We tried with dyneema early in the season and it stretched some â€“ Iâ€™m definitely a belt-convert for elevators after this season.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: The method we used involved circular grooves in each pulley instead of spirals and offsetting the top and bottom spools by half a groove. This caused the rope to move over by one full groove from top to bottom repeatedly, ensuring the rope always spools off the same points on the spools. This setup appears very similar to how some building elevators are rigged according to a reference link. Do you think this approach has any issues? Would you use it again in the future?

link_counts.title: Elevators 101: Donâ€™t Slip Up on Rope Configurations

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: many wraps do people use? the capstan equation is your friend here. tensioning rope that constantly "stretches" is annoying, and we are trying a belt for the offseason. how do you accommodate the wraps moving left and right? has anyone tried eliminating the fixed anchor in the middle of the spool? we tied the rope through a hole on the side of the spool, like the 111 picture, but a much thinner spool, and imagine a small hole in the plates that support the tube shaft. the tube was driven from outside of these rope retaining plates. we didn't bother to accommodate wraps moving, and were only punished by that if we lost tension in the rope, since our pulley was thin enough it couldn't walk very far left or right. if you have space for it, a turnbuckle in line with the spring is nice, since it makes it much easier to retie the elevator if the rope stretches enough that the spring is useless, or if the rope comes off of a pulley and it is too taut to easily get back on.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
An important note: I have never constructed nor been part of a team that built a multi-stage elevator; however, I recognize that a few theoretical aspects may exist. Regarding the biggest disadvantage associated with rope or smooth belts, unless you have an anchored reference point, you cannot rely on the position of the drive pulley as a substitute for elevator height. At minimum, you would require a couple of limit switches for calibration or recalibration purposes. When using cascade systems, anchors are generally easier due to shorter travel distances, but with continuous systems, achieving consistent results typically requires an unusually long constant-force spring, such as one found in tape measures. I stumbled upon this solution while attempting to construct a simple sensor setup for my 2015 single-stage elevator, though I did not implement it in competition. However, it inspired an idea, making it our most ambitious sensor concept up to that point. 

An alternative approach involves using multiple wraps, whether counter-rotating or not, which enhances grip on the pulleys for a given tension, addressing the aforementioned challenge. Counter-rotation minimizes differences in pulley twist. Additionally, when employing multiple wraps without counter-rotation, simply increasing pulley size and adjusting gearing proportionally can yield better results. To manage tension effectively, consider intentional over-tensioning or under-tensioning of springs during both match preparation and operation. This decision depends on how you configure your system before and after the match. Lastly, while I haven't tested this myself, experimenting with natural versus artificial materials, along with surface treatments, could prove beneficial if grip strength becomes an issue.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: The spring is there to account for the changing tension resulting from unequal/uneven tension as the Dyneema wraps over itself. If you use a continuous tension system or the drum method you can avoid the need for a spring. The best tensioning method involves ratchets. Dyneema must be checked regularly for chafe points to ensure confidence in the system. Itâ€™s easy to wear through it. Regarding stretch Dyneema doesnâ€™t really stretch once set. High-tech lines exhibit â€˜creep.â€™ A great article on this topic is available at [Samson Ropeâ€™s Technical Bulletin](https://www.samsonrope.com/docs/default-source/technical-bulletins/tb_understanding-creep_mar2012_web.pdf). Checking Dyneema regularly for chafe points is crucial. Most of the Dyneema used in robotics is the lower-quality non-pre-stretched version. At 20% load and a creep rate of .1%/month a typical 15-foot run would creep .18 inches in a month. What most teams refer to as â€˜stretchâ€™ is the knots working in and setting under load.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The capstans demand more rigidity in the elevator structure than a spooling winch. I owe everyone a big update this summer. What most robotics teams call â€˜stretchâ€™ is the knots working in and setting under time. Good rope tools and splices are the way to go. Splices settle in too, but (anecdotally) less than a figure 8 double loop or a bowline.

posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

How many wraps do people use As large of a diameter as reasonable. Larger diameter results in a lower fleet angle which makes things easier. Extra diameter does require more reduction but its a small price to pay for making the rigging just behave better.

If your fleet angle is small enough it should just behave. Helical grooves can be added to the spool to improve spooling behavior with larger fleet angles or in other suboptimal rigging setups and I generally recommend adding them anyway.

I mean you can do this but Iâ€™d rather just tie or clamp the rope off on the spool and never have to worry about if my tension is perfect or not.

Understanding that losing tension is what causes rope winches to tangle or slip. Whatâ€™s the best method to keep both ends of the rope tensioned Is a ratcheting drum anchor good enough or do you need a tension spring too?

A spring is required because spools have a fleet angle resulting in the elevator travel not quite being equal to the rope being unwound. Iâ€™ve tensioned rope successfully with as little as a single stiff spring and a clamp-off point but other features can be added to make tensioning easier.

What other gotchas advice to you have for working with continuous elevators and/or Dyneema rigging?

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Our team values reliability, and I saw too many teams with stripped elevator belts this year. For teams that used HTD Belt rigging this yearâ€”what worked and what didnâ€™t?  

We used PolyBelt belts on our elevator this year and couldnâ€™t be happier with the performance. Some will say that you absolutely must use the WCP belt or else an official Gates belt but my experience this season is that is not the case. The Polybelt belt is cheaper, is kevlar reinforced, and can be purchased by the foot.

posts.name: Christoforus Cedric Kurniawan
posts.cooked:
Our team used a continuous rope lift this year, heavily copying the Rusthounds RI3D. We had four different spoolsâ€”two to pull the lift up and two to pull it down. The "up" and "down" spools are wound in opposite directions.

The most critical aspect of performing a lift like this is ensuring all corresponding pulleys match. For instance, our carriage was pulled by two pulleys going upward, both requiring the same winding direction and exact number of wraps without overlapping. Overlapping caused uneven diameters and inconsistent tension. Similarly, the downward pulleys matched their counterparts but were wound oppositely.

Tensioning involved attaching the down spools to a REV turnbuckle linked to a spring connected to the carriage's bottom rail. Up spools used a screw with a REV Shaft Collar sized just for an #10 screw; tightening the screw adjusted the tension smoothly.

Friction between stages was an issue due to poorly manufactured REV MAXLift blocks. To initiate movement, we added surgical tubing under the carriage. Ideally, a CF spring might offer better performance.

The CAD wasn't fully updated, so spools weren't precisely designed, but pulleys were correctly placed. Our spools consisted of a VersaRoller between two Versahubs.

posts.name: Tom Praisner
posts.cooked: We used a pre-grooved spool with internal rigging using SDS elevator blocks. The system was very robust and relatively simple. I really like the idea of using a capstan drive for Dyneema-based rigging.

link_counts.title: Internal Elevator Rigging: A Simplified Approach Based on SDS Elevator Blocks

posts.name: Elin Kim
posts.cooked:
Our team created a single-stage internally rigged belt elevator for the first time this season. Many lessons were learned during this process, and similar experiences would apply if transitioning to a multi-stage setup.  

The elevator saved significant space due to its design involving belts between tubings. Creating elevators with ropes was a new experience, but proper belt tensioning meant minimal adjustments during the season. The elevator proved highly reliable, functioning consistently even when spools broke, though belt tension quality fluctuated.  

Several challenges arose, such as spool replacements needing strong materials and careful printing settings. Rigging added complexity, though thoughtful designs could simplify the process. Tubing slots required additional time for manufacturing. Costs for single-stage elevators were manageable, but multiple stages increased belt expenses.  

Thank you for your attention. Learning about elevator construction using ropes has been insightful!

We used WCP belt and ThriftyBot belt for our elevators (although theyâ€™re practically the same, they have the same spec, just different logos on the belts), and neither failed in any capacity. I have not seen a belt be the failing point for an elevator this season from any team.

As for elevator design, we stole @Eliot Belted Continuous Elevator with a few modifications

  • We used WCP Bearing Blocks instead of REV
  • Kraken X60s instead of NEOs
  • 5:1 MAXPlanetary Gearing

posts.name: Ohad
posts.cooked: Ill be honest, i dont know what youre looking for. i will say that in my experience getting dyneema products from reliable sources is hellish and for most applications kevlar rope is perfectly good.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: While our robot this year featured a straightforward continuous elevator equipped with dyneema rope, you can learn more about its design on our CAD Release, accessible via [this link](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/trigon-5990-cad-release-2025-tridog/500664). The system comprises three winches on a single shaftâ€”two for ascending and one for descending. The ascent ropes originate from the winches and pass through pulleys installed on each elevator stage. These ropes are secured with ratchets in the innermost stage to regulate tension effectively. The descent rope originates from the middle winch and connects to a small knob located at the bottom of the top elevator stage.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
This is the first I've ever heard about a stripped belt in an elevator. A team we're closely associated with (though not speaking for themselves) stripped one of their elevator belts just before the District Championship, necessitating some heroic measures to locate a replacement. Following this incident, at the Houston Championship, the pit announcers issued two separate requests for a "spare 30 ft length of HTD belt" during the event, indicating similar problems among other teams.  

I'm curious if pulley diameter and belt tension play a role in distributing loads across multiple teeth, but I'm unsure how to prevent belt failure. This led me to ask for clarification.
